p.text: “Admission” is defined in the Dictionary.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,735] s 81 Hearsay and opinion rules: exception for admissions and related representations

leg:heading.title: Hearsay and opinion rules: exception for admissions and related representations

p.text: The hearsay rule and the opinion rule do not apply to evidence of an admission.
The hearsay rule and the opinion rule do not apply to evidence of a previous representation:
that was made in relation to an admission at the time the admission was made, or shortly before or after that time, and
to which it is reasonably necessary to refer in order to understand the admission.
Specific exclusionary rules relating to admissions are as follows:
evidence of admissions that is not first-hand (section 82)
use of admissions against third parties (section 83)
admissions influenced by violence and certain other conduct (section 84)
unreliable admissions of accused persons (section 85)
records of oral questioning of accused persons (section 86)
D admits to W, his best friend, that he sexually assaulted V. In D's trial for the sexual assault, the prosecution may lead evidence from W:
that D made the admission to W as proof of the truth of that admission, and
that W formed the opinion that D was sane when he made the admission.
D admits to W, his best friend, that he sexually assaulted V. In D's trial for the sexual assault, the prosecution may lead evidence from W:
that D made the admission to W as proof of the truth of that admission, and
that W formed the opinion that D was sane when he made the admission.
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 755
ALRC 38 para 152

The term “admission” is defined in the Dictionary to include any previous representation made by a party that is adverse to its interest in the outcome of the proceedings. Because of the definition of “representation” in the Dictionary, the section includes implied admissions and admissions to be inferred from conduct. A lie also constitutes an admission for the purposes of the section: see R v Horton (1998) 45 NSWLR 426; 104 A Crim R 306; BC9805771 ; R v Reid [1999] NSWCCA 258; BC9905412 .

The exclusion of admissions from the hearsay and opinion rules is consistent with the common law position — under which admissions were admissible, in both civil and criminal proceedings, against the party by whom they were made. Moreover, an admission is admissible even if the party had no direct knowledge of the fact admitted and was required to rely, for their belief, upon statements of others or inferences from circumstances known or reported to them: Lustre Hosiery Ltd v York (1935) 54 CLR 134; 9 ALJR 314 ; see also Grey v Australian Motorists and General Insurance Co [1976] 1 NSWLR 669 at 684–5 and the authorities discussed therein.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,740] s 82 Exclusion of evidence of admissions that is not first-hand

leg:heading.title: Exclusion of evidence of admissions that is not first-hand

p.text: Section 81 does not prevent the application of the hearsay rule to evidence of an admission unless:
it is given by a person who saw, heard or otherwise perceived the admission being made, or
it is a document in which the admission is made.
Section 60 does not apply in a criminal proceeding to evidence of an admission.
[s 82 am Act No 53 of 2000 Sch 1 ; Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[35], effective 1 January 2009]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,745] s 83 Exclusion of evidence of admissions as against third parties

leg:heading.title: Exclusion of evidence of admissions as against third parties

p.text: Section 81 does not prevent the application of the hearsay rule or the opinion rule to evidence of an admission in respect of the case of a third party.
The evidence may be used in respect of the case of a third party if that party consents.
Consent cannot be given in respect of part only of the evidence.
In this section:
means a party to the proceeding concerned, other than the party who:
made the admission, or
adduced the evidence.

level.toc-caption: [50,745.5] Consent of a third party to the use of evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,745.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 83(2).

heading.title: Consent of a third party to the use of evidence

p.text: The provisions of s 83(2) are explicit and require the express consent of the third party. The section does not extend to the use of evidence in litigation which was not in contemplation when the agency was granted, when the relevant actions occurred: Custom Coaches (Sales) Pty Ltd v Frankish [2002] NSWSC 781; BC200205270 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,750] s 84 Exclusion of admissions influenced by violence and certain other conduct

leg:heading.title: Exclusion of admissions influenced by violence and certain other conduct

p.text: Evidence of an admission is not admissible unless the court is satisfied that the admission, and the making of the admission, were not influenced by:
violent, oppressive, inhuman or degrading conduct, whether towards the person who made the admission or towards another person, or
a threat of conduct of that kind.
Subsection (1) only applies if the party against whom evidence of the admission is adduced has raised in the proceeding an issue about whether the admission or its making were so influenced.
Legislation cited in [50,750.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 84, s 84(1).

An admission is not excluded under s 84 unless the evidence discloses a reasonable possibility that it was influenced by the conduct proscribed by the section. It is not necessary that the evidence establishes the actual probability of influence: Habib v Nationwide News Pty Ltd [2010] NSWCA 34; BC201001310 at [208]–[289] (statements made in the course of interrogation in Pakistan and Guantanamo Bay not admissible — not satisfied that the admissions were not influenced by s 84(1) conduct).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,755] s 85 Criminal proceedings: reliability of admissions by defendants

leg:heading.title: Criminal proceedings: reliability of admissions by defendants

p.text: This section applies only in a criminal proceeding and only to evidence of an admission made by a defendant:
to, or in the presence of, an investigating official who at that time was performing functions in connection with the investigation of the commission, or possible commission, of an offence, or

as a result of an act of another person who was, and who the defendant knew or reasonably believed to be, capable of influencing the decision whether a prosecution of the defendant should be brought or should be continued.
Subsection (1) was inserted as a response to the decision of the High Court of Australia in Kelly v The Queen (2004) 218 CLR 216 .
[subs (1) subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[36], effective 1 January 2009]
Evidence of the admission is not admissible unless the circumstances in which the admission was made were such as to make it unlikely that the truth of the admission was adversely affected.
Without limiting the matters that the court may take into account for the purposes of subsection (2) , it is to take into account:

any relevant condition or characteristic of the person who made the admission, including age, personality and education and any mental, intellectual or physical disability to which the person is or appears to be subject, and
if the admission was made in response to questioning:
the nature of the questions and the manner in which they were put, and
the nature of any threat, promise or other inducement made to the person questioned.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 765, 766
ALRC 38 paras 154(d), 158(c)
The terms “admission” and “criminal proceeding” are defined in the dictionary.

level.toc-caption: [50,755.15] Admissions by an accused in criminal proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,755.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 85, s 85(2), s 90.

heading.title: Admissions by an accused in criminal proceedings

p.text: The term “admission” is defined in the Dictionary. Any statement that is adverse to its maker in the outcome of the proceedings in which it is sought to be tendered is an admission for the purposes of the section, irrespective of whether it might otherwise be regarded as inculpatory or exculpatory: R v Horton (1998) 45 NSWLR 426; 104 A Crim R 306; BC9805771 ; R v Esposito (1998) 45 NSWLR 442; 105 A Crim R 27; BC9806173 . The Crown bears the onus of establishing that any admission was voluntary: R v Thompson [1893] 2 QB 12; Ibrahim v R [1914] AC 599 ; R v Askeland (1983) 8 A Crim R 338; Sailor v R (1992) 66 ALJR 268 ; R v Azar (1991) 56 A Crim R 44.

The provisions of s 85 are clearly expressed to apply only in a “criminal proceeding” as defined in the Dictionary: Fitz-gibbon v Wily (1998) 87 FCR 104; BC9804959 ; Rothmore Farms Pty Ltd (in liq) v Belgravia Pty Ltd (1999) 31 ACSR 88; 17 ACLC 847; [1999] FCA 598; BC9902226 .

The reference, in subs (2), to the “circumstances in which the admission was made” refers the actual making of the admission not the circumstances of the offence to which the admission relates: R v Rooke (NSWCCA, 60550 of 1996, 2 September 1997, unreported, BC9703981); R v Munce [2001] NSWSC 1072; BC200107784 ; cf R v Braun (NSWSC, Hidden J, 24 October 1997, unreported, BC9708080); R v Taylor [1999] ACTSC 47; BC9902699 .

There is a degree of overlap between the circumstances relevant to the application of s 85 , and those which are applicable to s 90 . As a consequence, there may be circumstances where it is open to a trial judge to conclude that the same circumstances which lead to the evidence not being rendered inadmissible by virtue of s 85(2) justify a refusal to exclude the evidence under s 90 . In the case of s 85 the onus of establishing admissibility rests upon the Crown whilst under s 90 , the onus rests upon the accused to demonstrate that the evidence should be rejected: Em v R (2007) 232 CLR 67; 239 ALR 204; [2007] HCA 46; BC200708428 at [63] ; Doklu v R [2010] NSWCCA 309; BC201009853 at [41] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,760] s 86 Exclusion of records of oral questioning

leg:heading.title: Exclusion of records of oral questioning

p.text: This section applies only in a criminal proceeding and only if an oral admission was made by a defendant to an investigating official in response to a question put or a representation made by the official.

A document prepared by or on behalf of the official is not admissible to prove the contents of the question, representation or response unless the defendant has acknowledged that the document is a true record of the question, representation or response.
The acknowledgment must be made by signing, initialling or otherwise marking the document.
In this section:
does not include:
a sound recording, or a transcript of a sound recording, or
a recording of visual images and sounds, or a transcript of the sounds so recorded.
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 769
ALRC 38 para 154(e)
Legislation cited in [50,760.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 164, 165.

At common law the court had a discretion to exclude an unsigned record of interview: Driscoll v R (1977) 137 CLR 517; 15 ALR 47 ; R v Devine (1985) 18 A Crim R 185 . The section goes further and renders any record of the questioning inadmissible unless it has been marked by the accused in some way as an acknowledgment of its accuracy. It has been held that if a disputed confessional statement or record of interview is signed but not reliably corroborated, a judge should warn the jury of the dangers of convicting the accused on the basis of that evidence alone: McKinney v R (1991) 171 CLR 468; 98 ALR 577; BC9102637 but see now ss 164 and 165 and the annotations thereto.

For the purpose of determining whether a previous representation made by a person is also taken to be an admission by a party, the court is to admit the representation if it is reasonably open to find that:
when the representation was made, the person had authority to make statements on behalf of the party in relation to the matter with respect to which the representation was made, or

when the representation was made, the person was an employee of the party, or had authority otherwise to act for the party, and the representation related to a matter within the scope of the person's employment or authority, or
the representation was made by the person in furtherance of a common purpose (whether lawful or not) that the person had with the party or one or more persons including the party.
For the purposes of this section, the hearsay rule does not apply to a previous representation made by a person that tends to prove:
that the person had authority to make statements on behalf of another person in relation to a matter, or
that the person was an employee of another person or had authority otherwise to act for another person, or
the scope of the person's employment or authority.
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 755
ALRC 38 para 152(c)
Legislation cited in [50,765.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 cl 6.
The following terms are defined in the Dictionary: “previous representation” and “admission”.
The circumstances in which a representation is to be taken as having been “made” by a person are set out in cl 6 of Pt 2 of the Dictionary.
Legislation cited in [50,765.13] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 87(1).

Paragraphs (a) and (b) of s 87(1) focus on the general authority of the person whose authority is in question, and not the authority to make the particular representation in question: Ingot Capital Investments Pty Ltd v Macquarie Equity Capital Markets Ltd (No 4) [2006] NSWSC 90; BC200511813 at [19] ; Refina Pty Ltd v Binnie [2009] NSWSC 311; BC200904012 at [8] .

Whether a lawyer has the authority to make a statement on behalf of a party is a question of fact. A lawyer retained to conduct legal proceedings is regarded as having an implied actual authority to make admissions for the purpose of the proceedings and to compromise them: Neale v Lennox [1902] AC 465 at 469 ; Elder v Cameron [2007] NSWSC 743; BC200705465 at [32] . There is a greater readiness to infer the requisite authority when the lawyer’s statement is made in connection with litigation, as opposed to non-litigious business. In the latter case, the scope of the lawyer’s authority typically becomes contentious where reliance is placed on the ostensible authority said to arise in the circumstances. The mere fact that a person is a lawyer does not, of itself, confer on them either actual or ostensible authority to contract on the client’s behalf: Pianta v National Finance & Trustees Ltd (1964) 180 CLR 146; 38 ALJR 232 at 234; BC6400840 . However, the nature of the retainer may justify implied authority to give or sign notices of particular kinds: Corazon Pty Ltd, Re (1987) 5 ACLC 1059; BC8700546 (notice of demand); Dennis Hanger Pty Ltd v Kanambra Pty Ltd (1992) 34 FCR 242; 106 ALR 544; 6 ACSR 687; 10 ACLC 284 (statutory demand under the Corporations Law); Pan Foods Co Importers & Distributors Pty Ltd v Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (2000) 170 ALR 579; 74 ALJR 791; [2000] HCA 20; BC200001744 (notice of demand under debenture); and it may also extend to making representations about matters within the scope of the retainer: Legione v Hateley (1983) 152 CLR 406 at 421; 46 ALR 1; BC8300063 (representations made in the course of a conveyancing transaction); CIC Insurance Ltd v Bankstown Football Club Ltd (1995) 8 ANZ Ins Cas ¶61–232; BC9403571 per Kirby P (scope of authority involved in a retainer to pursue an insurance claim). The difficulty of drawing a distinction between statements that are within authority as mere representations and statements that are relied on for their promissory effect, and arguably beyond the scope of a solicitor’s actual or ostensible authority was remarked on in CTM Nominees v Galba Pty Ltd (1982) 2 BPR 97147.

The words “reasonably open to find” as they appear in the section make it clear that the court does not have to make a concluded finding. The court merely has to be satisfied there is a reasonable basis on which such a finding could ultimately be made. The matter to be determined on the balance of probabilities is the existence of the reasonable basis, not the existence of the ultimate conclusion as to the authority, scope of employment or furtherance of a common purpose: see Director of Public Prosecutions v Brownlee [1999] NSWCCA 57; BC9901309 , cited in Tim Barr Pty Ltd v Narui Gold Coast Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 1247; BC200810320 at [11] .

For the purpose of determining whether evidence of an admission is admissible, the court is to find that a particular person made the admission if it is reasonably open to find that he or she made the admission.
The term “admission” is defined in the dictionary.
The section speaks of the court making a finding on the basis of what is “reasonably open”, not on the basis of conjecture: R v Hall [2001] NSWSC 827; BC200105794 .
In a criminal proceeding, an inference unfavourable to a party must not be drawn from evidence that the party or another person failed or refused:
to answer one or more questions, or
to respond to a representation,

put or made to the party or other person by an investigating official who at that time was performing functions in connection with the investigation of the commission, or possible commission, of an offence.
[subs (1) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[37], effective 1 January 2009]
Evidence of that kind is not admissible if it can only be used to draw such an inference.

Subsection (1) does not prevent use of the evidence to prove that the party or other person failed or refused to answer the question or to respond to the representation if the failure or refusal is a fact in issue in the proceeding.
In this section:
includes:
an inference of consciousness of guilt, or
an inference relevant to a party's credibility.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 756–757, 758
ALRC 38 paras 765–769

level.toc-caption: [50,775.10] Right to silence in criminal investigations

heading.title: Right to silence in criminal investigations

p.text: At common law, silence does not amount to an admission: R v Ireland (1970) 126 CLR 321; [1970] ALR 727; BC7000120 ; Hall v R [1971] 1 All ER 322. The section is consistent with, and largely reflective of, that principle: see Petty v R (1991) 173 CLR 95; 102 ALR 129; 65 ALJR 625 ; R v Anderson [2002] NSWCCA 141; BC200203253 ; R v Coe [2002] NSWCCA 385; BC200205631 . Accordingly, where an accused person exercises his right to silence, a direction should be given which does not undermine that right and which reminds the jury that no adverse inference can be drawn from a refusal to answer: Woon v R (1964) 109 CLR 529 at 535; [1964] ALR 868; BC6400050 .
In a criminal proceeding, the court may refuse to admit evidence of an admission, or refuse to admit the evidence to prove a particular fact, if:
the evidence is adduced by the prosecution, and
having regard to the circumstances in which the admission was made, it would be unfair to a defendant to use the evidence.
Part 3.11 contains other exclusionary discretions that are applicable to admissions
ALRC 38 para 160(b)
Legislation cited in [50,780.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 135, 137, s 85, s 85(2), s 90.

At common law, a trial judge has a residual discretion to reject evidence of an admission if, having regard to the circumstances in which the admission was made, it would be unfairly prejudicial to the accused to receive the document in evidence: McDermott v R (1948) 76 CLR 501 at 506–7 per Latham CJ, at 513 per Dixon J; [1948] 2 ALR 466; BC4800160 ; R v Lee (1950) 82 CLR 133; [1950] ALR 517; BC500050 ; R v Ireland (1970) 126 CLR 321; [1970] ALR 727; BC7000120 ; MacPherson v R (1981) 147 CLR 512 at 519–20; 37 ALR 81; BC8100115 ; Cleland v R (1982) 151 CLR 1 at 5; 43 ALR 619; BC8200128 per Gibbs CJ. The discretion is preserved and confirmed by s 90 : WorkCover Authority of NSW v Seccombe (1998) 43 NSWLR 390 at 402; (1998) 101 A Crim R 303 . The language of the section requires that there be an initial evaluation of whether or not, having regard to the circumstances in which the admission was made, it would be unfair to an accused to use the evidence, and then a decision made as to whether or not to refuse to admit the evidence of the admission. The evaluation and the decision combine to confer a discretion: see Em v R [2006] NSWCCA 336; BC200609570 at [54] . That, in turn, requires a balanced value judgment about the form and substance of the challenged admission, as well as a consideration of the circumstances in which the admission was made: R v Holt [2001] NSWSC 232; BC200101575 . In the exercise of the discretion under the section, it is not open to a court to conclude that the use of the evidence in criminal proceedings against the accused person would be unfair solely because of the manner in which, and the purpose for which, the evidence was obtained, if that manner and purpose were sanctioned by the Parliament: DPP v Attallah [2001] NSWCA 171; BC200103066 ; R v Lyberopoulos [2002] NSWCCA 280; BC200204075 ; Em v R, above; DPP v Majok [2009] NSWSC 192; BC200901815 . It is, however, relevant for the court, in considering what is fair or not fair, to have regard to the role played by the person who has created the circumstances said to be unfair. This is to be contrasted with the concept of unfairness in ss 135 and 137 which is directed to questions of whether a jury might adopt an illegitimate form of reasoning, whether it would give the evidence undue weight, or reason emotionally or illogically: R v Bakir [2009] NSWDC 12; BC200940100 .

There is a degree of overlap between the circumstances relevant to the application of s 85 , and those which are applicable to s 90 . As a consequence, there may be circumstances where it is open to a trial judge to conclude that the same circumstances which lead to the evidence not being rendered inadmissible by virtue of s 85(2) justify a refusal to exclude the evidence under s 90 . In the case of s 85 the onus of establishing admissibility rests upon the Crown whilst under s 90 , the onus rests upon the accused to demonstrate that the evidence should be rejected: Em v R (2007) 232 CLR 67; 239 ALR 204; [2007] HCA 46; BC200708428 at [63] ; Doklu v R [2010] NSWCCA 309; BC201009853 at [41] .
